== Psychological perspectives ==
 
== Psychological perspectives ==
 
Psychologists have gathered data on commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social [[Psychology]], 49, 607–62.</ref>
 
Psychologists have gathered data on commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social [[Psychology]], 49, 607–62.</ref>
−
These analyses indicate that although "there is an overlap of the implicit theory of wisdom with intelligence, perceptiveness, spirituality and shrewdness, it is evident that wisdom is a distinct term and not a composite of other terms."<ref>Brown, S. C., & Greene, J. A. (2006).i personally think widom is bad.The Wisdom Development Scale: Translating the conceptual to the concrete. Journal of College Student Development, 47, 1–19.</ref> Many, but not all, studies find that adults' self-ratings of perspective/wisdom do not depend on age.<ref name="CSVperspective" /><ref name="Orwoll">{{cite book|last=Orwoll|first=L.|coauthors=Perlmutter, M.|title=Wisdom: Its nature, origins, and development|editor=R. J. Sternberg|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|year=1990|pages=160–177|isbn=0521367182}}</ref> This stands in contrast to the popular notion that wisdom increases with age.<ref name="Orwoll" /> In many cultures the name for third molars, which are the last teeth to grow, is etymologically linked with wisdom, e.g. as in the English ''[[wisdom tooth]]''. In 2009, a study reviewed which brain components were related to wisdom.<ref>[http://archpsyc.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/66/4/355 Neurobiology of Wisdom: A Literature Overview].</ref>

In 2009, a study reviewed which brain components were related to wisdom.<ref>[http://archpsyc.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/66/4/355 Neurobiology of Wisdom: A Literature Overview].</ref>
     
Researchers in the field of [[positive psychology]] have defined wisdom as the coordination of "knowledge and experience" and "its deliberate use to improve well being."<ref name="CSV106">{{cite book
